Still, this place is worth it for the ambiance and service alone--think richly decorated, upscale and 1920's. Walls are covered in sumptuous fabrics and patterns with bright blasts of maroon and teal. The whole place exudes indulgence. Just be sure to book a table. It fills up fast.

So I would consider this the most upscale and good quality Chinese-ish food you can have! Girl and the Goat is one of my favorite restaurants, so I knew I had to try this while in Chicago. I was able to make a reservation about a month in advance and they were attentive in confirming the reservation and asking for food allergies ahead of time.

Walking in, the decor certainly looks like early 1900s, Chinese inspired. Lots of red and oriental shapes. At the table the duck duck goat logo on the chopstick wrapper struck my eye, so cute and you will see this logo in some of their merch as well.

The menu feels nostalgic but inspired at the same time and for a party of 6, we were able to sample a bunch of awesome dishes:

- Egg drop soup: this is probably the most ingredients I have ever seen in an egg drop soup, which was welcome. The egg doesn't look as broken up flowery as the traditional one, but taste wise, it was great
- Ham sui gok: the goat dumpings. This was a pretty gamey dumping and it was an awesome surprise with the punch in flavor from the meat compared to the traditional ground pork
- Xiao long bao: again with the twist of goat, which made the broth within even more flavorful. Beware, the skin is thin, so unfortunately there were some breakage at our table
- Green beans: This is a favorite at any Chinese restaurant for me, but somehow Duck Duck Goat was able to elevate this dish where it doesn't taste quite as greasy, but still maintains some of the traditional and wonderful black bean sauce flavor
- Duck fried rice: So fun to break the duck egg over the rice! I will say that the consistency of the fried rice could have had a bit more of a bite, it was a bit one note in texture
- Beef slap noodles: I love the thick noodles that look hand pulled and short ribs over it was saucy and delicious
- Branzino special: This is a take of sorts on the ginger and scallions steamed fish. but with mushrooms, which made it earthy. The meat was moist and it was awesome to put that over the fried rice
- Jian dui donut holes: generally I am a sucker for jian dui and reading the menu where it said "sesame whip" I was even more excited, but really it was just little donut hole sized jian dui (sesame balls) that didn't have a filling, and really good whipped cream, but it was not sesame flavored. I was slightly disappointed in being mislead on this one
- Mango coconut cloud: The fruit and the cloud in this dish were a great combo and a nice acidic but sweet finish to our meal. I was most excited about the dragon fruit in this dish.

Walking into this trendy restaurant is a fun experience!  Come here for a date or when entertaining some out of towner friends.  The decor is antique Chinese throw back to the 1800-1900s ambiance.  Think, "old school movies" from a 1920s Shanghai-type scene.

The environment is a little loud with music and conversation abound.  It's dark too but despite the large space, they have managed to still keep each table feeling fairly cozy and intimate...except in the open seating around the bar.

The menu is interesting taking its cues from classic Chinese dishes from all regions and giving it a modern, urban interpretation at times.  If you read Chinese, please ignore some of their translations / names of their dishes.  Some just don't make sense or do not describe the actual food as one would expect.  But don't be disappointed.  The food is still actually quite good.  Their interpretation is faithful enough to its Chinese roots while still giving a fresh and solid taste to the dishes.

Was looking forward to this meal, but was disappointed.  We went on a Sunday at 5:15 pm, using an OpenTable reservation.  The service was bad.  We were starving, so the beef wonton soup was delicious.  We also got the pickled cucumbers and octopus/cucumber/peanut salad, which were both very good, but also very similar.  The seafood fried rice was nothing special.  And the Sichuan chicken was ok.  We did get the mango coconut cloud dessert, which was very good!  Cute decor.  Menus are look like an old, used chinese restaurant menu.  Oh, we did get the green beans, which were good!  We were visiting for the wknd and our other meals, included Sepia, Parachute, and Mott Street.

Pretty good chinese restaurant that looks like a real fine dining chinese restaurant from Shanghai or Hong Kong from the 1920s-30's. Quite refined, so don't expect the regular chinese food, nor the prices, which are, quite high. As with many restaurants of this class some portions can be rather small - for the price that is. Went there with 2 other friends. Ordered 2 appetizers, the bone marrow potstickers - Jiazo, very, very good and the Xiao Long Bao, steamed baos but filled with a soup, think little bags of soup. A 1st for me, but very tasty. We also ordered as an appetizer the Dan Dan noodles. Think noodles with a peanut flavored bolognese. Rich and flavorful. The appetizers were over $11 dollars each with $15 for the noodles. For main dish we shared a Peking Duck, that at $59 looked expensive, but it ended up being a deboned, nicely presented bird and a fairly large. Flavor was on point. Not greasy as this dish regularly is with a very crispy skin.

Service was really good with very knowledgefull waiters who really knew the menus and could explain them really well

This place is an interesting dining option that is pretty singular, at least it was for me. Be ready for an over $100 dollar bill. Our meal was around $165 with tip. My only issue is that I think you can find relatively similar food in chinatown for more than half. If you can foot the bill try it. Chinatown will not be as nice for sure.

Fulton Market District has been renovated and there are tons of newer options to try out. We decided to stop into Duck Duck Goat to grab some appetizers. If this was Monopoly, Stephanie Izard would be kicking all of our butts. Her other two restaurants, Girl and the Goat and Little Goat Diner, are within walking distance. Duck Duck Goat has just as tasty fare as the rest of them.

So the focus here is dim sum. I gotta say, though, this is pretty fancy dim sum. Also, the prices don't scream dim sum to me, either. The portions are decent and help soften the wallet blow, though. We sat in the bar area and ordered a few beers, the potstickers, and the pork buns. The pork buns came out huge and pillowy. The dough was tasty and the filling was pretty perfect, too. The potstickers were also delicious and had a bit of sauce already drizzled on them for extra flavor.

The bar was pretty busy, but you can sit and stare at all of the decor in the restaurant while you wait. It does feel like you are stepping into a Chinese village marketplace or something to get some quick bites.

The only thing is that the bartenders were moving a bit too quickly that night and I ended up having water poured into my beer. It would have been nice to have it replaced with no questions asked instead of asking me to let him know if it was ruined. It was still quite full. However, my beer took one for the team and I let it slide. Service was still friendly, nonetheless.

So yeah, Duck Duck Goat is pretty swanky for dim sum. The food is tasty. Prices are higher than your normal dim sum restaurant, but I still think it's worth it to check this place out at least once.

Last but not least! After having dined at girl & the goat and little goat diner, we finally got the chance to see what duck duck goat was all about. The ambiance here is definitely more upscale and trendy compared to a traditional Chinese restaurant.

As for the food, the way to do it here is family style. We started off with one of the dim sum items, jiaozi, which was the beef short rib and bone marrow pot stickers. Seemed to be one of the more popular item here but it actually ended up being our least favorite. The texture of it was very mushy so we were a bit worried what was next to come. However, the other three dishes that we ordered: octopus, cucumber, peanut salad, beef slap noodles, and the duck fried rice were all pretty good. I highly recommend ordering the octopus salad. It's very light, refreshing, and the flavors were well-balanced. The waiter originally suggested two dim sum items, a noodle or fried rice, and one of the larger main dishes but what we ordered was more than enough between the two of us and had left overs to take home.

All in all, Stephanie Izard didn't disappoint!

I was so impressed by this place from the decor to the service, the whole experience was perfect.  I ate here with a couple friends the other night and immediately after stepping foot into the restaurant was so amazed by the ambiance, I almost forgot I was in Chicago.

For appetizers we got the Jiazo (beef short rib and bone marrow potstickers) and scallion pancakes both which were mouth watering.  We also got the green beans in black bean sauce which was a little on the salty side - the only thing on the menu I could've gone without that night.  

Otherwise everything else was 5 star worthy... for our main entrees we ordered the Duck Fried Rice that featured a soft boiled egg which blended perfectly into the rice... then we had the Hongshao Rou (the pork belly) which was cooked ever so perfectly it was so tender as you cut into it and melted right in your mouth.

For dessert we got the almond tofu and miso sundae.  The sundae was this tasty array of tapioca and sweet bean while the "tofu" had an ever so light taste of vanilla and almond which wasn't too sweet.

Awesome experience! Servers are incredibly helpful and make sure to know of everyone's dietary restrictions to better guide their dining choices.

We had made reservations ahead of time, which could be a helpful decision in busier nights. All items are family style and are meant for sharing, we were a group of 6 with 9 dishes to share and we had leftovers remaining.

I would definitely recommend this place to eat!

I've always loved Chinese food, but I often have trouble finding Chinese restaurants that I like. Duck Duck Goat did not disappoint, and I can see myself coming back here to try more items from their menu in the future.  The vintage wallpaper, unique light fixtures, and calming color scheme creates a memorable atmosphere.  This restaurant has a respectable amount of wines, beers, and cocktails to start your meal with.  I ordered the smoking ginger cocktail (Bourbon,  Whiskey, Ginger, Honey, Lemon, Egg White, 5 Spice and Angostura Bitters), and I loved how unique it tasted compared to other cocktails I've had with similar ingredients.

The appetizers and main entree's are meant for sharing, and this place would be a great place to check out with a large group of people.  My friend and I shared an order of the bao's, and those were pretty good.  I ordered the seafood fried rice, and I really liked this dish as well.  I sampled the beef slap noodles that my friend ordered, and I kind of liked this dish more than the dish that I ordered.  Every food item I tasted was well seasoned, but not overly heavy on salt.  The prices seemed to be in line with the high quality of the ingredients used in the food dishes.  Most of the main entree's were between $15-$20, so this place has prices that wont break the bank too much.

I didn't expect this place to have authentic authentic Chinese food, but the food was pleasantly good and better than I could have imagine. I give props to the chef.

When you first walk in, you see this blend of western and Chinese decor. I would not expect to see this in any traditional Chinese restaurant. Modern yet they were able to emphasize the importance of the color red and green in their culture.

This restaurant had the absolute best char siu bao (steamed bbq pork bun) I've had in my life. The dough was extremely light with just the right touch of sweetness to it. I also loved the duck fried rice. The egg on top was a nice touch. With the xiao long bao, the dumplings could have been less flat when we got them. They appeared to be deflated, and they really didn't taste very special compared to other places I've tried. The beef slap noodles were perfect in texture, but had an overpowering lemon after taste to it.

I thought the most clever part of the meal was the fortune cookie. Instead of the traditional fortune cookie, we got a round cookie and a pin that had a fortune on it. Genius. I still have my pin.

I am visiting Chicago for a conference, and one my friends suggested us to eat for dinner last night. I was a little concerned because the menu did  not seem vegetarian friendly, but I was wrong! They have an exclusive vegetarian menu, and by was everything delicious.
We started of with their summer special which was zuchinni and squash which tasted like kimchi!
Even though I was on the only vegetarian in my party, everyone ordered vegetarian food so we were able to try multiple entrees. We started off with the scallion cakes which were very good and not very oily which I loved. We also ordered the glass noodles which was delicious with the right amount of spice. The green beans in black bean sauce was so good. I was so excited about this dish because not many chinese restaurants have black bean sauce which I love. They added crispy peanuts and wonton paper on top which gave it the perfect crunch. The mapo doufu was very good and not salty like other restaurants because they add mushrooms to absorb the salt. The only thing  i wish that it came with rice (you have to order it separately).
This was there perfect amount to share amongst the three of us.
I was thoroughly impressed, and so glad that I was able to come here!

This place is so pretty, makes you feel like you are in Shanghai. Great for a romantic date.
The food is classic Chinese with a twist, great portions very easy to share. They have delicious cocktails as well. Overall very positive experience.

I love the decor of this restaurant. It is traditional yet cozy! The menu seems traditional of a Chinese restaurant as well.

To start I had a vodka drink which has charcoal in it. It came out black but it was very refreshing and tasty.

For dinner I had the beef slap noodles, if you are not adventurous this is perfect for you! It's a simple yet delicious dish which consists of a shredded beef sauce and long thick noodles. It was very filling for one but all dishes are meant to be shared family style.

I also had the bbq bao, I was so full from my noodles I couldn't enjoy it as much but the breading was very soft and the meat was tender. Overall good flavor.

The portions are big. If you are sharing dishes, I would just order one dish per person to share.

I am by no means an adventurous eater! I'm quite picky... however, on my recent visit here I tried the duck and goat spring rolls (crispy, meaty, and the dipping sauces are good) and the beef and bone marrow dumplings, both quite good. We also enjoyed the scallion pancakes, veggie fried rice (a little too greasy), and the chili fried chicken. I very much enjoyed my dinner here.

My favorite part of the meal was they drink called Jade Gate! It is a tequila based drink with flavors of green tea, apple, and pistachio. Delicious, please try it! I think I'll definitely be back next time I'm in Chicago!

Love love love this place! All of the dumplings are fantastic! The bone marrow ones are super but also super rich and creamy. Nice balance to some shrimp ones! Also - all the positive reviews on the duck fried rice are not wrong!

Duck Duck Goat is part of Boka Group, which is home to arguably the best EVER collection of foodie spots in all of Chicago. Stephanie Izard can do no wrong.

We came here on a Tuesday night for dinner and were immediately taken with the vintage Shanghai atmosphere. The ambience is almost transformative, though it only takes looking at the crowd to remember you're still in Chicago. It's a big date night and post-work spot for those in the Loop.

Our server was super sweet; when we asked which of the two rosé options were drier, like we preferred it, to our surprise, she suggested that we order neither, and advised us to order a bottle from the glass-only options. This hidden third option ended up being the cheaper and honestly, most delicious. She kept the bottle chilled away from the table and was very mindful of ensuring our glasses were always full during the course of dinner.

We started with Char Siu Bao (steamed barbecue pork buns) which were plump, airy and brimming with delicious filling. They were a little dry and could benefit from some type of dipping sauce, but still a very yummy dish. We next tried the Scallion Pancakes off our server's recommendation, which were crisp and delicious. We also tried a side of the green beans in black bean sauce, which was one of the chef's specialties. There's a decent sense of umami there, with the crispy onions, garlic and beans, but it came off a little overly salty and oily.

We also split the duck fried rice which was rich and gorgeous and silky and oooooh, mama, so good. I love a runny yolk and the duck egg was sublime. And finally, the Hongshao Rou (2 pieces of fatty, tasty, red braised pork belly) was a show stopper. Melts in your mouth like a piece of savory cotton candy. Generally, we found the dishes to be the stars of the experience and the dim sum to be a little lackluster. Is it worth going back? Maybe; I knew I had to try it at least once, but we came out thinking we'd have just as satisfying a meal at our local takeout place for a fraction of the price. That being said, the service is excellent, the atmosphere one of a kind, and it's absolutely worth trying at least once.

After trying Duck Duck Goat, I'm a believer that anything by Chef Izzard is a guaranteed great dining experience. My friends and I ordered some dishes to share: the Xiao long bao was a favorite of the table and I burnt my lip because I was too impatient to let the dumplings cool down, the pecan chicken dish was my least favorite and I left this mostly untouched which was fine by my friend who ate it up, the beef slab noodles were ordered by accident but they ended up being amazing, and the duck fried rice was packed full of flavor. I really liked the cookies that came out with the check in lieu of fortune cookies. I thought the dishes were great, but I've def had better versions of all these dishes elsewhere.

If you're on the fence about going to this place based on the mixed reviews do yourself a favor and go somewhere else. This is the most ridiculous place to ever try and call itself fine dining. In short, reservations mean nothing here and the food is barely edible. Not worth the money, not even worth going for the experience.

We called over two hours in advance to reserve a table for two at 10:00pm on a Saturday night which was their earliest availability. We came in around 9 to see if they had any earlier tables or at least let them know we were in the area so we could be checked in. We went up the street to the arcade to wait for the reservation and went back at 9:45. At that point the hostess was telling us the people where we were supposed to be sat were done eating but were just sitting there. At that time another party of two walked in saying they had a reservation. They waited a while as well but chose to leave out of the place. Then another party of two came in with or without a reservation. Somehow both of these two parties were sat before us by another hostess that was clearly in contact with our hostess even though we were there and checked in first for 10:00pm. Keep in mind there is no way these people had a 9:30 or 9:45 reservation because when we called at 8:00 the only opening was for 10:00 and had the others had an earlier slot they would have arrived prior to 9:45 which they had not. I'm pretty sure reservations work by what tables are available not by, oh I want you to sit here so no matter what other tables we have open you have to sit at this one spot. So we were sat at a tabletop to keep us from waiting any longer which is right at the bar and I'm pretty sure it is bar seating until they put the reserved sign on it. If we wanted to sit at the tabletop we would have sat there when we came in at 9. So now we waited all this time for nothing. To add insult to injury the hostess then tries to sit someone at our tabletop as if it was not our reservation at this point. Furthermore, I saw several open tables where we could have been seated at.

The wait staff here is really nice, that's about the only positive thing I can say about this place. We ordered the beef and bone marrow wontons, chicken rice noodles, and duck fried rice. Everything was really overpriced for the portion and just overall quality of the food. Nothing was particularly hot, I would not be surprised if it was microwave food. It probably would have been better if we had gotten frozen Chinese from target, that's how bad and funky the food tasted. Nothing spectacular about any of the dishes, all of them had the same grease and smoke taste except some were sweet and some were salty. There was barely any duck in the fried rice and I'm not sure what kind of "salted" the egg was but there was no flavor to it besides grease and water. While I was eating the rice there was this huge chunk of some kind of minty seed in the food that was so hard and big that it hurt my mouth and I had to spit the entire bite of food out. That ruined any hope left for the dish. The only remotely interesting thing was that the rice noodles in the chicken had an good texture. The only worthwhile things we ordered were the drinks which came out of a can. While we were waiting for the waiter to come and pack our food and get the check the bartender took eaten food left at the bar and put it on our table as if she could not pick the plate up, wipe the counter, and put it back down. What part of fine dining is that?

If you just want to try a new place I suggest eating somewhere else and only come here for a small plate and drinks. Do not come here expecting anything fine dining besides the prices. This is honestly the most ghetto restaurant I have ever been to, you would be better off going to a chain.

I love this place! This is the second time I've come here for brunch/dim sum with two friends.  Stephanie Izard was  here working in the kitchen this visit!  The cocktails are always delicious. I had the win some you dim sum- it was delicious.  Gin and grapefruit is a pairing I love.  My friends got the hibiscus drink which was also very good.  We ordered 5 dishes among the three of us, and it was the perfect amount.  We left very content - if we ordered a couple more, we would have been stuffed.  We had the glutinous rice dumplings with goat. They were so good!  Very hot, so be careful!  The green beans were very good! Similar to Girl and the Goat green beans.  We also ordered the soft shell crab special, that was very good In a garlic bean sauce.  The goat slap noodles were amazing.  They're a little spicy with a lot of cumin.  I love cumin, so it was great, but if you don't, this isn't for you.  We also had the scallion pancake which I had the last time, too.  It's quite delicious if I do say so myself.  The food and service here are always amazing.  There are few restaurants I go back to, because there are always so many new ones to try!  This one is definitely one I go back too :)

pics.caption: Chiu chow fun gor - shrimp and peanut dumplings.
Short rib slap noodles.  Very good.  Love the chewy noodles.
Jiazo- short rib and bond marrow pot stickers.  Delicious, very flavorful.  Highly recommend.

review.des:
Delish!  Omgoodness we came here for Mother's Day and left feeling fuller than most days because this place can serve up some scrumptious carbs!   First, I fell in love with the decor as it is different in every room - call it Chinatown vintage...?  Such a fun atmosphere, I immediately thought fun dim sum night with friends.  We had a lovely server who was attentive and friendly and all staff we encountered here were equally as sweet.

We ordered up 7 plates to share and left with plenty for two plus leftover meals.  They recommend 2 plates per person and there were three of us.  

Here's what we ate (this was off a dim sum brunch menu - so, limited)

Beef Wonton Soup - GET IT (the most delicate yet rich short rib/marrow stuffed wontons in a tasty beef broth with lots of ginger, little greens, plenty of chili oil added a kick and MAJOR flavor) served in a crock for 3-4

Xi'an Crispy Potatoes - think smashed baby potatoes, then crisped up - crazy tasty and drizzled in an aioli - enough for 4-5 ppl

Pig Face Buns - savory pig face (this is literally pig meat from the cheeks, don't be scared cause it's everythang!) in a flaky yet sturdy pocket (aka bun) the sauce is horseradish'y  - 3 pc.

Duck Fried Rice with soft boiled duck egg on top - whoa.  The richest, most delicious jasmine rice flavored perfectly with duck meat strewn throughout plus veggies and all that duck fat nom nom. 3 ppl easy

Scallion Pancakes - the pancake is like condensed layered filo dough with scallions which is amazing by itself, however, the slaw they serve with it can be mixed in with any other fork full of food on our plates and it was FOURTH OF JULY IN MY MOUTH so good.  omg. 2-3 ppl

Taiwanese Fried Chicken - good and tender dark meat, but honestly we could have skipped it.  I would have preferred a protein not fried on top of all the other dough we consumed - it was just too much for us at this point in the meal.  3-4 ppl big bowl full

String Beans w cashews - These were charred with what felt like crispy onions and cashews and they were yummy and added some greens where we needed them

I'd go back with a group.

Oh Drinks!  I had the Ping Pong which was a vodka libation with tumeric, carrot and something else plus tapioca balls - it was awesome (10.00)

Tab was 140.00 with three alcoholic dranks

This place takes a modern and more fancy spin on the traditional Chinese take out. The decor of the place is awesome- looks like somewhere straight out of 1950s china very cool and coordinated for an integrated experience.

They warn you that the food is not authentic chinese and it definitely isn't but it is still quite good. The portions are smaller than would expect from a Chinese place or little goat diner but is more close in size to girl and the goat.
Octopus cucumber peanut salad: 5/5 best thing I've tried there. Very light and refreshing with well balanced flavors
Seafood fried rice: 3/5 was not that special
String beans: 5/5 super good string beans. I have had string beans in a lot of restaurants and while this one isn't authentic it is delicious topped with shallots to give it a great crunch!
Pecan chicken: 4/5 chicken and pecan was glazed thinly with a good crunch but was a little too sweet for my taste

Drink:
Jade gate 4/5
Lucky duck 4.5/5

They give you an almond cookie at the end of the meal which is nice. Would like to come back to this place and the dining experience is great but but the price is a little high for the portions and quality.

Was there for a coworker gathering lunch. The food was good but there some dishes I felt it's too spicy or oily. I love their dumpling and pancake. The interior design of the restaurant is very unique. There are pictures and art piece hung on the ceiling or evening place on the edge. There outdoor seating.

I'm not a huge Chinese fan so I didn't even eat much but the VIBES in here are INCREDIBLE so unique I've never seen such a thriving and vibrant restaurant atmosphere. Definitely seems like a big foodie spot. The music was fun, and the restaurant was decorated in such a cool way. I had so much fun just being in there

Such a fan of Stephanie Izard restaurants! Duck Duck Goat was literally the best Chinese I have ever had! Literally! I'm not so much a fan of goat but they way they prepare it here you couldn't even tell! Deff come early or make reservations cause this place gets full quick!

PS: If Aaron Sanchez is chowing down here then you know you're eating something good! He was such a pleasure to chat with!

pics.caption: Deep fried duck tongue with shishito peppers.
Duck fried rice with braised egg.

review.des:
Finally a restaurant of the goat franchise that didn't disappoint me.  The ambience is romantic with nice decor. The food is pretty good and the service is excellent.

You should definitely get reservation because the place was packed when we went. My friend and I got the beef soup, the pecan chicken, and beef noodles. We also got some of their emperor pu'erh tea.

The beef soup was TERRIBLE. Seriously, I get that the broth is supposed to bed salty, but ours was inedible. There's was 0 flavor and just tasted like they'd poured a bottle of soy sauce over some beef and veggies and dumplings and called it a day. Skip this one at all costs.

The chicken was delicious! It was crispy and coated in a delicious sauce. The pecans were a nice addition.

My personal favorite dish was the beef noodles. The sauce was so good and the beef was nice and tender.

The portions sizes are deceptively small. My friend and I got 3 dishes but we were full after eating the chicken and the beef noodles (we couldn't finish the disgusting soup).

The tea was also super delicious.

Btw, the take next to us got the whole duck which looked incredible, but wasn't practical for my friend and i to get because there was only 2 of us. I wish they would make a smaller portion available for small parties. Will have to go back and try that with a larger group.

pics.caption: Beef soup. Avoid at all costs. Just tastes like a bottle of soy sauce.
Chicken with pecan and beef noodles

review.des:
Best Peking Duck I have ever had! Went there for my birthday dinner and was not disappointed, in fact I was downright impressed.
We ordered the shrimp toast, green beans,szechuan eggplant, shishito peppers, and Peking duck!
Everything was wonderful- the veggies perfect, the duck is the best Peking I have ever eaten!
I had the mango cloud for dessert- o.m.f.g. - is was totally the bomb!!
The service was good, unobtrusive, and casual , much like the place.
I totally recommend the experience-
Ambiance- Food-Service
One warning- It would be a crime to skip the mango cloud when dessert is offered.

This place is amazing. I went there for the second time and the food is outstanding and the flavors are amazing. This was my first time eating at the bar and the service was tremendous and sincere. At the end of my meal, the bartender brought us a whole other dish compliments of the house because there were extras! It put me over the edge with fullness, but every bite was well worth it. If you're looking for some unique dishes with amazing flavor, check it out

Wait : 1 hour for Saturday night at bar
Environment : decor is legit, roomy
Service: friendly and helpful
Drink : cocktails are great,
Food : really delicious

My girlfriend brought me here after she thoroughly enjoyed her meal last time she visited. Unfortunately, in an effort to branch out and order some different dishes, I ended up picking some options that weren't as good as we were hoping. Boys suck, don't they?

Anyway. We started off with the fermented veggies, which were just bad. They were really sour, and the vegetables they used were just so weird. Like pickled green beans and cauliflower? I was expecting a lighter, sweeter dish like the one at traditional Taiwanese/Chinese restaurants, but this was not it at all. The jiaozi, or beef short rib and bone marrow potstickers, were amazing. The outside wrapping was so crispy and the bone marrow helped make the filling so creamy and rich, and the soy sauce-like sauce was just the perfect dressing. The wood-fired char siu ribs were not my girlfriend's favorite, but I enjoyed them. There was a lot of bone, however, and not much meat. It's similar to the Wuxi ribs dish served at Chinese restaurants, but not as sweet. I enjoyed them, I just wish there wasn't such a huge hunk of bone!

We also ordered the veggie fried rice which was great. It was a bit oily and salty, but great nonetheless. The kicker, though, was the almonds!! Such an interesting texture with the chewy rice. Finally, we got the green beans in black bean sauce which was also excellent. This was probably the closest to a traditional dish, minus the crispy onion straws, which were actually a really good addition!

Overall, this place is NOT a Chinese restaurant. Unfortunately, I was unable to put aside my expectations for these dishes, so I was left longing for more. However, Duck Duck Goat has certainly managed to put its own twist on Chinese food and add a unique flavor. The food is excellent, and I'm willing to give it the benefit of the doubt and come back, with better options -- and letting my girlfriend order instead ;)
